title: What causes insomnia? - Dan Kwartler

multiple-choice.question: What is the world's most common sleep disorder?
What factors can contribute to occasional restless nights?

options.label: A
options.text: Physical pain and emotional distress only

options.label: B
options.text: A snoring partner and extreme sleep deprivation only

options.label: C
options.text: Various factors, including a snoring partner, physical pain, emotional distress, and extreme sleep deprivation

multiple-choice.question: What effect does extreme sleep deprivation have on the body's biological clock?

options.label: C
options.text: It is disrupted and thrown off

multiple-choice.question: What types of long-term conditions can overpower fatigue in some cases?
What happens to the brain's primary source of energy during healthy sleep?

options.label: D
options.text: The metabolism slows down to conserve glucose for waking hours

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the brain's supply of energy-giving glucose in insomniacs during sleep?

options.label: D
options.text: The body burns through it due to increased metabolism

multiple-choice.question: What is the relationship between the chemical mechanisms of insomnia and those of depression and anxiety?

options.label: C
options.text: They share some common underlying factors

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the best-understood treatments for insomnia?

options.label: A
options.text: Managing stress that leads to hyperarousal

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the genetic problem that can be misdiagnosed as insomnia?
What is vital to maintain for our physical and mental wellbeing?

options.label: C
options.text: A delicate balance between sleeping and waking cycles

title: You can grow new brain cells. Here's how - Sandrine Thuret

multiple-choice.question: What term describes the phenomenon of generating new nerve cells in the adult brain?
Which brain structure is known for its ability to generate new neurons in the adult brain and plays a crucial role in learning, memory, mood, and emotion?
According to research, approximately how many new neurons are produced daily in the human hippocampus?
What are some of the key functions of new neurons in the hippocampus?

options.label: C
options.text: Learning, memory, mood regulation, and differentiating similar memories

multiple-choice.question: How do antidepressants affect symptoms of depression when neurogenesis is increased?
Which behaviors or activities decrease the production of new neurons in the hippocampus?
What type of diet has been shown to negatively impact neurogenesis?
Which compound has been shown to promote the survival of new neurons?
What type of food texture has been found to impair neurogenesis?
What are the primary goals of neuroscientists studying neurogenesis?

options.label: C
options.text: Understand new neuron function and control their survival and production

options.text: Nasal conchae (curved structures in the nasal passages)

options.label: C
options.text: Sinus cavities (air-filled spaces in the skull)

multiple-choice.question: What percentage of people is estimated to have some type of misalignment to their nasal septum?

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: Nasal conchae (curved structures in the nasal passages)

multiple-choice.question: What can cause irritation to the blood vessels in the nasal septum, leading to an anterior nosebleed?

options.label: D
options.text: Any of the above, as well as a vigorous blow or a roaming finger

multiple-choice.question: What effect does dry air have on the mucous membrane in the nose?

options.label: A
options.text: It becomes more resistant to bleeding

options.label: D
options.text: It becomes more susceptible to bleeding

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: Pinch the soft part of the nose for 10 minutes and lean forward

options.label: B
options.text: Use a nasal spray to numb the area

options.label: C
options.text: Use a bandage to cover the nose

options.label: D
options.text: Cauterize the blood vessel using silver nitrate

multiple-choice.question: What should you avoid doing when you have a nosebleed to prevent further irritation or injury?

options.label: B
options.text: Applying gentle pressure to the nose

options.label: D

title: Why do I have to use a number 2 pencil?

multiple-choice.question: Why do test instructions often recommend using a number 2 pencil for automatically-scored tests?

options.label: A
options.text: The lead in number 2 pencils is less prone to breakage.

options.label: B
options.text: The graphite in number 2 pencils makes the darkest possible marks.

options.label: C
options.text: The graphite in number 2 pencils is the softest available.

options.label: D
options.text: The graphite in number 2 pencils makes marks that are just dark enough to be sensed by machines and light enough to be erased.

multiple-choice.question: What property of graphite made it suitable for use in Reynold Johnson's early mark-sensing machines?

options.label: A
options.text: It is highly abrasive and resistant to wear.

options.label: B
options.text: It is electrically insulating, making it difficult for electricity to pass through.

options.label: C
options.text: It is electrically conductive, allowing electricity to pass through when a mark is made.

options.label: D
options.text: It is highly reflective, making it difficult to detect by phototubes.

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of using softer graphite in a pencil?

options.label: A
options.text: The mark made by the pencil is lighter.

options.label: B
options.text: The pencil is more prone to breakage.

options.label: C
options.text: The mark made by the pencil is darker.

options.label: D
options.text: The pencil is less likely to be used by machines.

multiple-choice.question: Why are number 2 pencils preferred for use on exams with optical mark-sensing machines?

options.label: A
options.text: The graphite in number 2 pencils is too soft for machines to detect.

options.label: B
options.text: The marks made by number 2 pencils are more likely to be erased, resulting in less accurate scoring.

options.label: C
options.text: The graphite in number 2 pencils is less conductive than other types of graphite.

options.label: D
options.text: The marks made by number 2 pencils strike a balance between being dark enough to be sensed by machines and light enough to be erased.

multiple-choice.question: What is a feature of modern scoring machines?

options.label: A
options.text: They can only detect marks made by number 2 pencils.

options.label: B
options.text: They use phototubes to detect marks.

options.label: D
options.text: They can detect almost any type of mark as long as it's in the bubbles.

multiple-choice.question: Who is credited with devising a machine that could score exams without manual intervention?

options.label: B
options.text: A high school physics teacher named Reynold Johnson

multiple-choice.question: Why did the number 2 pencil recommendation become an issue in the 1960s and 70s?

options.label: A
options.text: The machines used to score exams were upgraded to use more advanced sensors.

options.label: B
options.text: The machines used to score exams were replaced with manual scoring.

options.label: C
options.text: The machines used to score exams began using light-sensing devices called phototubes.

options.label: D
options.text: The machines used to score exams became less accurate.

multiple-choice.question: What property of graphite makes it useful for blocking light in optical mark-sensing machines?

options.label: A
options.text: It reflects most light and absorbs the rest.

options.label: B
options.text: It absorbs most light and reflects the rest.

What is the international equivalent of a number 2 pencil?

title: Why are we ticklish?

options.label: B
options.text: It creates a confusing mix of pain and pleasure

options.label: C
options.text: It is a response to a gentle, soothing touch

options.label: D
options.text: It is a widespread phenomenon in mammals

Which areas are commonly vulnerable to tickling in primates?

options.label: B

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: C
options.text: We wouldn't learn how to defend ourselves effectively

title: How old are your ears? (hearing test)

multiple-choice.question: What typically happens to our hearing spectrum as we grow older?

options.label: A
options.text: We gain the ability to hear higher frequencies.

options.label: B
options.text: We lose the ability to hear lower frequencies.

options.label: C
options.text: We lose the extreme ends of our hearing spectrum.

multiple-choice.question: What frequency can people who are not hearing impaired typically hear?
What type of cells in the ear are responsible for picking up different frequencies and sending the signal to the brain?

options.label: C
options.text: Hair cells, a type of nerve cell

multiple-choice.question: Why do people tend to lose their ability to hear high frequencies first as they age?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the hairs tuned to low pitches experience more stress.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the hairs tuned to high pitches are the first to encounter sound waves.

options.label: C
options.text: Because the inner ear becomes less sensitive to sound.

options.label: D
options.text: Because the ears are more sensitive to low frequencies.

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the hair cells in the ear due to prolonged exposure to noise and loud sounds?

options.label: D
options.text: They break, bend, and are destroyed.

multiple-choice.question: What is the consequence of the hair cells degenerating?

options.label: A
options.text: We gain the ability to hear higher frequencies.

options.label: B
options.text: We lose the ability to hear lower frequencies.

options.label: C
options.text: We lose the ability to hear high pitches.

multiple-choice.question: Which of the following organs have the capacity to regenerate?
Which of the following organs does not have the capacity to regenerate?
What age group is likely to be able to hear all frequencies?
What is the main topic of the video?

options.label: C
options.text: How our hearing changes with age

title: What if you never forgot anything?

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the famous patient known for his severe type of amnesia, where he was unable to form new memories of facts or events after undergoing a surgery that damaged his hippocampus?
According to the transcript, what is the nature of a memory in the brain?

options.label: A
options.text: A physical object stored in a specific brain cell

options.label: B
options.text: An action that occurs when many connected neurons fire in a specific pattern

options.label: C
options.text: A type of chemical reaction that occurs in the brain

options.label: D
options.text: A localized electrical impulse in a single brain region

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of consolidation in the brain?

options.label: A
options.text: To store new memories in long-term storage by strengthening connections between brain cells

options.label: B
options.text: To retrieve old memories from long-term storage

options.label: C
options.text: To delete old memories from long-term storage

options.label: D
options.text: To create new memories from scratch

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is the difference between passive oblivescence and motivated forgetting?

options.label: A
options.text: Passive oblivescence is a type of forgetting that happens intentionally, while motivated forgetting is a type of forgetting that happens unintentionally

options.label: B
options.text: Passive oblivescence is a type of forgetting that happens unintentionally over time, while motivated forgetting is a type of forgetting that happens intentionally

options.label: C
options.text: Passive oblivescence occurs due to interference from new memories, while motivated forgetting occurs due to emotional suppression

options.label: D
options.text: Passive oblivescence occurs during wakefulness, while motivated forgetting occurs during sleep

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, how does the brain's ability to forget contribute to our ability to learn and remember new information?

options.label: A
options.text: The brain's ability to forget hinders our ability to learn and remember new information

options.label: B
options.text: The brain's ability to forget has no impact on our ability to learn and remember new information

options.label: C
options.text: The brain's ability to forget is necessary for learning and remembering new information, as it allows us to clear out junk and update our mental models

options.label: D
options.text: The brain's ability to forget is separate from our ability to learn and remember new information

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the medical condition where a person has an extremely detailed memory of their past?
According to the transcript, what is the difference between memorization and true understanding?

options.label: A
options.text: Memorization is a type of understanding, while true understanding is a type of memorization

options.label: B
options.text: Memorization is a surface-level understanding, while true understanding requires seeing how concepts are related and dealing with new information

options.label: C
options.text: Memorization is necessary for true understanding, but not sufficient

options.label: D
options.text: Memorization is the same as true understanding

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is one way to sharpen one's brain and develop critical thinking skills?

options.label: A
options.text: By solving logic and deduction problems, such as those found on Brilliant

options.label: B
options.text: By watching educational videos on critical thinking

options.label: C
options.text: By reading books on unrelated topics

options.label: D
options.text: By playing strategic games without critical thinking components

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is one potential benefit of being able to forget?

options.label: A
options.text: One would never forget anything, including painful memories

options.label: B
options.text: One would never remember anything, including important events

options.label: C
options.text: One would be able to move past traumatic life events and clear out junk

options.label: D
options.text: One would never learn anything new

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is one potential drawback of having a perfect memory?

options.label: A
options.text: One would never forget anything, including painful memories, and may be haunted by regrets

options.label: B
options.text: One would never remember anything, including important events

options.label: C
options.text: One would never learn anything new

options.label: D
options.text: One would never forget anything, but would also never remember anything

title: When will the next ice age happen? - Lorraine Lisiecki

multiple-choice.question: What term do geologists use to describe the period approximately 20,000 years ago when ice sheets reached their maximum extent?
Over the last million years, how many different glacial maxima have occurred?
What is one of the primary drivers of massive swings in Earth's climate?

options.label: B
options.text: Changes in atmospheric carbon dioxide levels

options.label: D
options.text: Shifts in the planet's rotation rate

multiple-choice.question: What event, occurring about 700 million years ago, caused Earth to become almost entirely covered in ice?
Approximately how much did the sea level rise 20,000 years ago when the ice sheets began to melt?
What combination of processes causes the Earth's axis to wobble, altering the amount of sunlight that strikes different parts of its surface?

options.label: D
options.text: A combination of axial precession, orbital eccentricity, and changes in Earth's tilt

multiple-choice.question: Approximately how often do changes in Earth's orbit cause the climate to shift from a glacial maximum to a warmer period?

options.label: A
options.text: To predict the exact date of the next glacial maximum

options.label: B
options.text: To understand the causes of climate change and inform strategies to mitigate its effects

options.label: C
options.text: To study the effects of climate change on specific ecosystems

options.label: D
options.text: To develop new technologies to combat climate change
